C API » Data Access

Detailed Description

A cursor is used to navigate the contents of a table or the result of an SQL query.

To obtain a cursor handle for a table, call db_open_table_cursor. To create a cursor from an SQL statement, call db_prepare_sql_cursor and then db_execute.

See also
CAPISQL, Table Cursor

Allow forward scan.

#define DB_CAN_MODIFY   0x00000100u

◆ DB_SCAN_BACKWARD

#define DB_SCAN_BACKWARD   0x00000008u

Allow backward scan.

◆ DB_CAN_BOOKMARK

#define DB_CAN_BOOKMARK   0x00000200u

Bookmarks can be used with the cursor.

◆ DB_CURSOR_TYPE_FORWARD

#define DB_CURSOR_TYPE_FORWARD   0x00001000u

A forward-only cursor cannot seek to prior rows or directly to the last row.

◆ DB_CURSOR_TYPE_STATIC

#define DB_CURSOR_TYPE_STATIC   0x00002000u

A static cursor buffers each row; once visited, the value of a row will not change until the cursor is closed or unexecuted.

◆ DB_CURSOR_TYPE_DYNAMIC

#define DB_CURSOR_TYPE_DYNAMIC   0x00003000u

A dynamic cursor is sensitive to changes in the result set, but only if visible to the connection.

◆ DB_CURSOR_TYPE_EXCL

#define DB_CURSOR_TYPE_EXCL   0x00008000u

Used in combination with a cursor type; fail if that cursor type is not supported.

◆ DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_ANSI

#define DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_ANSI   0x00000000u

Query string and literals use ANSI encoding.

◆ DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF8

#define DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF8   0x00010000u

Query string and literals use UTF-8 encoding.

◆ DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF16

#define DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF16   0x00020000u

Query string and literals use UTF-16 encoding.

◆ DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF32

#define DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF32   0x00030000u

Query string and literals use UTF-32 encoding.

Function Documentation

◆ db_duplicate_cursor()

db_cursor_t db_duplicate_cursor ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_flags_t  flags 
)

Duplicate a cursor.

Both cursors reference the same data, but can have different positions and flags. Both cursors must be closed using db_close_cursor when no longer needed.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
flagsCursor flags. Use DB_DUPLICATE_SAME_FLAGS to duplicate the flags used by hcursor.
Returns
  • Handle to duplicate of given cursor.
  • NULL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid cursor handle.
See also
db_close_cursor, db_get_cursor_flags,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_close_cursor()

db_result_t db_close_cursor ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Close a cursor.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Invalid cursor handle.
See also
db_duplicate_cursor, db_get_cursor_flags,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_find_field()

db_fieldno_t db_find_field ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
const db_objname_t *  field_name 
)

Identify a field in a cursor by name.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
field_nameField name.
Returns
Field number or -1 on failure. The error code DB_ENOTFOUND is set if the field was not found.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.

◆ db_bof()

int db_bof ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Check whether the cursor has passed the beginning of the table.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • (1) Cursor has moved past the beginning of the table.
  • (0) Cursor has not moved past the beginning of the table.
  • (-1) Invalid cursor handle.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.

    See also
    db_eof, db_seek_prior,
    get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_eof()

int db_eof ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Check whether the cursor has passed the end of the table.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • (1) Cursor has moved past the end of the table.
  • (0) Cursor has not moved past the end of the table.
  • (-1) Cursor is not browsable, invalid, or does not support forward scanning.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
See also
db_bof, db_seek_next,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_bind_columns()

db_result_t db_bind_columns ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
const db_bind_t *  binds,
db_fieldno_t  nbinds,
size_t  row_array_size,
size_t  row_bind_type,
size_t *  num_rows_fetched 
)

Bind column buffers before reading data from a cursor with db_fetch_scroll.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
bindsArray of absolute field bindings.
nbindsNumber of fields in binds.
row_array_sizeNumber of rows for block binding, or 1 for single-row binding.
row_bind_typeThe size of each array element for row-wise bindings, or DB_ROW_BIND_BY_COLUMN for column-wise bindings.
[out]num_rows_fetchedA buffer for the number of rows fetched, or NULL.
Returns
  • Row handle.
  • NULL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: number of fields being bound is 0, binding structure is not valid.
  • DB_EBINDSIZE Invalid bind size. Data type and size don't match.

db_bind_columns defines the buffers into which a rowset will be fetched by subsequent calls to db_fetch_scroll. Each binding in binds associates a cursor field with a C data type, and a column buffer of that type.

Warning
The memory address of each column buffer is saved in the cursor. Column buffers must remain valid until the cursor is closed or db_bind_columns is called again.

For single-row binding, each binding must be an absolute binding to a variable or buffer, and row_array_size must be exactly 1.

For row-wise block binding, each binding must be an absolute binding to a member of first element of a pre-allocated C struct or C++ class array, and row_bind_type must be the size of the first element. row_array_size is the number of elements in that array.

For column-wise block binding, each binding must be an absolute binding to the first element of a pre-allocated array for that column, and row_bind_type must be DB_ROW_BIND_BY_COLUMN. row_array_size is the number of elements in each such array, which must be the same for every column.

Column bindings can be replaced at any time. Each call to db_bind_columns replaces all column bindings previously associated with the cursor.

See also
db_fetch_scroll,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_fetch_scroll()

db_result_t db_fetch_scroll ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_seek_position_t  new_position,
int64_t  offset,
int64_t *  num_rows_fetched 
)

Fetch one or more rows from the cursor into previously bound columns.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
new_positionNew position for cursor; one of:
  • DB_SEEK_BEFORE_FIRST
  • DB_SEEK_FIRST
  • DB_SEEK_NEXT
  • DB_SEEK_PRIOR
  • DB_SEEK_LAST
  • DB_SEEK_AFTER_LAST
  • DB_SEEK_RELATIVE
  • DB_SEEK_ABSOLUTE
offsetOffset for relative or absolute seek. A relative offset may be negative.
[out]num_rows_fetchedUnless num_rows_fetched is null, it is assigned the number of rows fetched into the rowset.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_ENOMOREDATA The cursor has no more data to fetch.
  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
  • DB_ESTATE Cursor does not support requested seek operation.
Precondition
Before calling db_fetch_scroll, columns must be bound to the cursor with db_bind_columns and, for SQL cursors, executed with db_execute.

db_fetch_scroll reads one or more rows from the cursor, writes that rowset to the bound columns of the cursor, and moves the cursor to the beginning of the next rowset. To read all data available from the cursor, call db_fetch_scroll in a loop until it returns DB_ENOMOREDATA, processing the rowset between each call.

Forward-only SQL cursors cannot use a negative offset or a new_position of DB_SEEK_PRIOR, DB_SEEK_LAST, or DB_SEEK_AFTER_LAST.

See also
db_bind_columns, db_execute,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_set_position()

db_result_t db_set_position ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_seek_position_t  new_position,
int64_t  offset,
int64_t *  numrows 
)

Move the cursor to a new position.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
new_positionNew position for cursor; one of:
  • DB_SEEK_BEFORE_FIRST
  • DB_SEEK_FIRST
  • DB_SEEK_NEXT
  • DB_SEEK_PRIOR
  • DB_SEEK_LAST
  • DB_SEEK_AFTER_LAST
  • DB_SEEK_RELATIVE
  • DB_SEEK_ABSOLUTE
offsetOffset for relative or absolute seek. A relative offset may be negative.
[out]numrowsNumber of rows actually advanced. The value is negative if the cursor moves backward. Use NULL if this information is not needed.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
  • DB_ESTATE Cursor does not support requested seek operation.

Forward-only SQL cursors cannot use a negative offset or a new_position of DB_SEEK_PRIOR, DB_SEEK_LAST, or DB_SEEK_AFTER_LAST.

See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_check_position()

db_result_t db_check_position ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_flags_t  test,
db_flags_t *  result 
)

Check the cursor position for boundary conditions.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
testBitwise combination of positions to check for:
  • DB_IS_BEFORE_FIRST
  • DB_IS_AFTER_LAST
[out]resultActual position of the cursor.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid or result is NULL.
  • DB_ENOTIMPL Invalid test flag.

The result is either zero or a combination of the test flags.

Postcondition
(*result & test) == test
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_seek_first()

db_result_t db_seek_first ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Move the cursor to the first row in the table or result set.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
See also
db_seek_last, db_seek_next, db_seek_prior,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_seek_next()

db_result_t db_seek_next ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Move the cursor to the next row in the table or result set.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.
Note
If the cursor is on the last row in the table and db_seek_next is called, the cursor will not have a current row and db_eof will return true.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
  • DB_ESTATE Cursor does not support forward scanning.
  • DB_ENOMOREDATA Cursor is already positioned after the end of the table.
See also
db_seek_prior, db_seek_first, db_seek_last,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_seek_prior()

db_result_t db_seek_prior ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Move the cursor to the previous row in the table or result set.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.
Note
If the cursor is on the first row in the table and db_seek_prior is called, the cursor will not have a current row and db_bof will return true.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
  • DB_ESTATE Cursor does not support backward scanning.
  • DB_ENOMOREDATA Cursor is already positioned before the beginning of the table.

Forward-only SQL cursors cannot use this function.

See also
db_seek_next, db_seek_first, db_seek_last,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_seek_last()

db_result_t db_seek_last ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Move the cursor to the last row in the table or result set.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Cursor handle is invalid.
  • DB_ESTATE Cursor does not support forward scanning.

Forward-only SQL cursors cannot use this function.

See also
db_seek_next, db_seek_first, db_seek_prior,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_fetch()

db_result_t db_fetch ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_row_t  hrow,
db_object_t  uobject 
)

Store the contents of the current row in hrow.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
hrowDestination for fetched data.
uobjectRow data for relative bindings. Use NULL if hrow does not contain relative bindings.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid cursor handle, invalid row handle.
  • DB_ENOTFOUND Cursor is not positioned on a row. No data was read.
Postcondition
A transaction is active on database if the operation succeeds.
See also
db_insert, db_update, db_delete,
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_qfetch()

db_result_t db_qfetch ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
const db_bind_t *  binds,
db_len_t  nbinds,
db_object_t  uobject 
)

Fetch data from the current row using a binding array.

db_qfetch is a convenience function that combines db_alloc_row and db_fetch. For best performance in tight loops, use db_alloc_row outside the loop and db_fetch inside the loop.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
bindsArray of bindings.
nbindsNumber of fields in binds.
uobjectRow data for relative bindings. Use NULL if hrow does not contain relative bindings.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invlid cursor handle, relative field binding is null.
  • DB_EBINDSIZE Invalid bind size.
  • DB_ERANGE Argument is out of range. Number of fields < 0 or number of feilds > binds.size.
  • DB_ENAME Invalid field name used in binding.
  • DB_ENOTFOUND Cursor is not positioned on a row. No data was read.
Postcondition
A transaction is active on database if the operation succeeds.
See also
get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling
